Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a State-of-the-Art Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide funding to replace two old mass spectrometers with a state-of-the-art Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer (TIMS) to complement the existing Triton in the Isotope Geochemistry Laboratory at the University of Maryland. The new instrument will be installed in the space currently occupied by the two old mass spectrometers that it will replace. Specific analytical tasks to be tackled with the new TIMS instrument include: 1) high precision 182W, 142Nd-143Nd, and 186Os-187Os isotopic analysis of ancient through young mantle-derived materials, as a means of studying the evolution of early Earth reservoirs and rates of mantle mixing through time, 2) high precision measurement of Ru and Mo isotopes in early Earth rocks to search for diverse, late accreted components to Earth, 3) measurement of Os isotopic composition and abundance as a means of studying the timing, formation mechanisms and secondary processes involved in the generation of subcontinental lithospheric mantle, 4) measurement of Os isotopic composition and abundance in subduction zone materials as a tool for tracing mantle wedge contributions to m√©lange zones, 5) measurement of Nd and Sr isotopes in Antarctic granites as petrogenetic tools, and 6) analysis of Sr isotopes in carbonates to gauge relative rates of hydrothermal and terrestrial inputs to seawater through time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided partial funding for the purchase of a new, state-of-the-art thermal ionization mass spectrometer. This instrument is used to measure isotopic ratios of certain elements to very high precision. The instrument was purchased and delivered to the University of Maryland in 2014. To date, the instrument has been used to quantify very small differences in the isotopic compositions of the elements neodymium and tungsten (specifically the isotopes Nd-142 and W-182) in rocks that formed on Earth more than two billion years ago. These differences are the result of radioactive decay that occurred within the first five hundred million years of Earth history. They record large-scale processes that occurred within the Earth's mantle when the Earth was young. The most likely process these differences record is large-scale melting and subsequent crystallization of the Earth's mantle, soon after the Earth grew to its present size. The fact that these small but significant differences in isotopic composition survived within the mantle for more than two billion years indicates that convective mixing of the mantle was relatively inefficient, even during the hotest period of Earth's history. We have also measured tungsten "anomalies" in young rocks, indicating that the primordial reservoirs within the mantle that formed early and retained the isotopic characteristics of these extraordinarily early-Earth processes may still be present as chemically distinct domains within the mantle today.
